title: Cost of EU Parliament set to soar as new President to be protected by 12 BODYGUARDS
text:
Cost of EU Parliament set to soar as new President to be protected by 12 BODYGUARDS Cost of EU Parliament set to soar as new President to be protected by 12 BODYGUARDS THE cost of security for MEPs and staff at the European Union’s Parliament is set to rise again with President Antonio Tajani to be protected with 12 bodyguards. PUBLISHED: 10:57, Thu, Feb 23, 2017 | UPDATED: 11:00, Thu, Feb 23, 2017 
The Parliament’s Secretary General Klaus Welle has drawn up the plans, contained in the draft estimates for the financial year in 2018. 
The document was presented to the Parliament’s executive committee, also known as ‘the Bureau’ on February 13. 
Mr Welle has consulted with three departments in the Parliament, which has 751 MEPs, and “recruitment procedures of these bodyguards will start early 2017”. Getty Belgium soldiers patrol outside the EU Parliament 
The security unit will comprise 34 “armed personnel” and one manager with the purpose of “ensuring the security of strategic points within European Parliament premises.” 
The security will also cover cyber issues and the Parliament will have a team of 26.5 full-time staff, composed of both Parliament officials and external consultants. 
The European Commission already has its own “close protection” unit for President Jean-Claude Juncker and Commissioners who face a heightened security risk. The cost of running the European Parliament in 2015 was £1.52 billion (€1.795bn) with 34 percent being spent on staff, interpretation and translation costs. 
In 2017 the EU Parliament spent £36.7 million (€43.3m) on security with £21.2m (€25m) spent on security staff and over £15.2m (€18m) on buildings. 
The minutes of a meeting at the college of Commissioners on February 8 indicate that Commissioner Günther Oettinger who oversees the Commission’s human resources and security department, was joined by Commissioner Julian King, who is responsible for the developing the EU’s ‘Security Union’, in calling for “greater vigilance, particularly as regards cyber security.” Getty EU Parliament President Antonio Tajani Related articles
